intro: Eadesia anthocercidea, commonly known as the red-stemmed mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaceae and is characterized by its small, fleshy leaves and clusters of bright red berries. The plant derives some of its nutrients from the host through specialized root structures called haustoria. It is typically found in tropical and subtropical regions, often in forested areas. Its berries are an important food source for birds and other wildlife.
